notes:
1. Phase Relationships

Index properties are used to describe the state of a soil, particularly the relative proportions of solids, water, and air. Key properties include:

  • Water Content ($w$): Ratio of the weight of water to the weight of solids ($W_w/W_s$).
  • Void Ratio ($e$): Ratio of the volume of voids to the volume of solids ($V_v/V_s$).
  • Porosity ($n$): Ratio of the volume of voids to the total volume ($V_v/V_t$). $n = e/(1+e)$.
  • Degree of Saturation ($S$): Ratio of the volume of water to the volume of voids ($V_w/V_v$).
  • Specific Gravity ($G_s$): Ratio of the unit weight of solids to the unit weight of water (typically 2.6-2.8).

The fundamental relationship connecting these is: $Se = wG_s$.

2. Atterberg Limits

These limits define the water content boundaries between different states of fine-grained soils (clays and silts):

  • Liquid Limit ($LL$): The water content at the boundary between the liquid and plastic states.
  • Plastic Limit ($PL$): The water content at the boundary between the plastic and semi-solid states.
  • Plasticity Index ($PI$): The range of water contents over which the soil behaves plastically. $PI = LL - PL$.
  • Liquidity Index ($LI$): Compares the natural water content ($w_n$) to the limits. $LI = (w_n - PL) / PI$. If $LI > 1$, the soil is in a liquid state.

3. Particle Size Distribution

Coefficient of Uniformity ($C_u$): $D_{60}/D_{10}$. Indicates the range of particle sizes.
Coefficient of Curvature ($C_c$): $D_{30}^2 / (D_{10} \times D_{60})$. Indicates the shape of the gradation curve.
A well-graded soil has a wide range of sizes ($C_u$ is high) and a smooth curve ($C_c$ between 1 and 3).

solvedExamples.question: A saturated soil sample has a water content of 25% and a specific gravity of solids of 2.70. What is the void ratio?
solvedExamples.explanation: Use the fundamental relationship $Se = wG_s$. Since the soil is saturated, $S = 1$ (or 100%). Convert water content to a decimal: $w = 0.25$. So, $1 \cdot e = 0.25 \cdot 2.70$. $e = 0.675$.

solvedExamples.question: A soil has a Liquid Limit of 60 and a Plastic Limit of 25. What is its Plasticity Index?
solvedExamples.explanation: The Plasticity Index (PI) is simply the difference between the Liquid Limit and the Plastic Limit. $PI = LL - PL = 60 - 25 = 35$.
